bestBHT.bht: The act of asking, seeking, and knocking is intricately tied to the parable mentioned. Christ's use of the word ask highlights the equality between Him and the Father. The repeated command suggests that seeking goes beyond mere asking, and knocking goes further than seeking. Those who persistently ask, diligently seek, and earnestly knock will witness the opening of the door to God's mercy, fellowship with Christ, comprehension of the Gospel, and access to heaven.

Henry Alford: The asking, seeking, knocking, all answer to the features of the parable.
What follows is in the closest connexion.
It will not bear the idea that it is transferred here merely as being appropriate.
Marvin Vincent: Christ never uses the word of his own asking from the Father, but always ejrwtw, as asking on equal terms.
Martha shows her low conception of his person when she uses the term of his asking God.
The three repetitions of the command are more than mere repetitions; since to seek is more than to ask, and to knock than to seek.
Archibald T. Robertson: Shall be opened (ανοιγησετα). Second future passive third singular of ανοιγνυμ and the later ανοιγω.
John Gill: Ask, and it shall be given you...whether it be bread for the body, or food for the soul; or any blessing whatever, whether temporal or spiritual, it shall be given."
Seek, and ye shall find...such shall not lose their labour, but shall enjoy all these valuable things, and whatever they are by prayer, and in the use of other means, seeking after."
Knock, and it shall be opened to you...the door of mercy with God; the door of fellowship with Christ; the door of the Gospel and the mysteries of it; and the door of heaven.

bhtAttempts.bht: The asking, seeking, and knocking in Luke 11:9 all correspond to the elements of the parable. What follows is directly connected to this idea and is not simply included for the sake of relevance. Christ, in his interactions with the Father, always uses the word ask on equal terms. The repetition of the command underscores that seeking is more than asking, and knocking is more than seeking. The second future passive form of the verb open in shall be opened indicates that the door of mercy with God, the door of fellowship with Christ, the door of the Gospel, and the door of heaven will be opened to those who earnestly ask, diligently seek, and persistently knock.

The asking, seeking, and knocking mentioned in this passage are all connected to the parable. Christ always uses the word ask on equal terms with the Father, emphasizing their relationship. The repetition of the command highlights that seeking goes beyond asking, and knocking goes beyond seeking. Through these actions, the door of mercy with God, the door of fellowship with Christ, the door of the Gospel, and the door of heaven shall be opened to those who persistently ask, diligently seek, and earnestly knock.

The concept of asking, seeking, and knocking in this verse is closely linked to the parable. Christ always asks the Father on equal terms, demonstrating their relationship. The repeated command signifies that seeking surpasses asking, and knocking exceeds seeking. Those who consistently ask, diligently seek, and earnestly knock will find that the door to God's mercy, fellowship with Christ, understanding of the Gospel, and entrance to heaven will indeed be opened.

The act of asking, seeking, and knocking is intricately tied to the parable mentioned. Christ's use of the word ask highlights the equality between Him and the Father. The repeated command suggests that seeking goes beyond mere asking, and knocking goes further than seeking. Those who persistently ask, diligently seek, and earnestly knock will witness the opening of the door to God's mercy, fellowship with Christ, comprehension of the Gospel, and access to heaven.

The act of asking, seeking, and knocking in this verse corresponds to the elements of the parable. Christ always uses the word ask on equal terms with the Father, emphasizing their relationship. The repetition of the command emphasizes that seeking is more than asking, and knocking is more than seeking. Through these actions, the door of mercy with God, the door of fellowship with Christ, the door of the Gospel, and the door of heaven shall be opened to those who diligently ask, persistently seek, and earnestly knock.
